column1: Will Russia officially recognize the Donetsk People's Republic and/or the Luhansk People's Republic in Ukraine as independent states before 1 September 2022?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Feels like we should remove the question....
It already happened
Fait accompli.
And there ya go!
That was quick.

Russian news has already focused on Ukrainian attacks on the two breakaway states, and hybrid war is already in place. Putin needs some concession from lining up troops in Ukraine, and creating a Abkhazia/South Ossetia situation in DPR/LPR fits the bill. In addition, it acts as an unofficial block towards NATO because it freezes a territorial dispute which Western Europeans do not want to be involved in. Finally, recognizing and placing troops in DPR/LPR is not strong enough action for the west to impose a strong retaliation. This is a low cost victory for Putin because of de-facto control and limited scope, exactly the types of actions he is incentivized to do -- and has done in the past.
it did.

The probability for this to occur is practically coupled to the probability of an actual invasion; As the Crimea region of the Ukraine is more than just a strategic foothold along the Western Black Sea, it is also a source of nationalistic pride in that it was a territory of Russia as far back as Catherine the Great, and thus, it is likely that Putin is looking to justify an invasion through claiming that defending the DPR is a necessary action to protect Russian interests (and the legacy of Putin's regime).
Putin announced that he is going to do it.

Well, he just did. https://www.dw.com/en/putin-to-recognize-ukraine-separatist-regions-as-independent-kremlin/a-60861963?maca=en-newsletter_en_bulletin-2097-xml-newsletter&r=47277061244719920&lid=2062420&pm_ln=135404

Well looks like my earlier predictions were way off! Putin has just said Russia will shortly recognise the independence of both regions: https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2022/feb/21/russia-ukraine-news-latest-crisis-putin-biden-summit-kyiv-kiev-russian-invasion-threat-live-updates
News reports today that Putin will announce recognition of the two breakaway regions.
Done
it seems a quasi certainty now
Seems extremely likely at this point
Up 5%. If I'm wrong, my Brier will be similar to many.
Yes, Putin is going to decide to... most probably not recognize the aforementioned republics and keep this as a threat in his pocket, at least for now.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-60468234 Story says Putin will decide today whether to do this, and then may feel a need to invade Ukraine to protect those regions. One feels very little suspense but some trepidation.
Putin says he will decide 'by end of day' whether to do it
https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/02/21/world/ukraine-russia-putin-biden

A recognition will end the Minsk Process, and will actually help Ukraine long-term. On the other hand, it can help Putin show an achievement for the buildup, and allow Russian forces to open a new front vs. Ukraine.
Buck the trend. Not convinced.
It is not in the interest of Putin and Co to recognize Donetsk and Luhansk. It is better to leave it as a sore on Ukraine body.

The Duma can put forward any provisions or laws. In part, they are implemented, but not always officially confirmed. It was the same with the Duma vote in 2014, when they voted to send troops to Ukraine, but Putin did not officially confirm it. The situation is similar now, but Putin will not go against the whole world, because recognizing these groups as "independent states" will put him in an awkward position. @Oluwoje
there are a lot of ways this could go that don't involve independence. E.g. direct annexation by Russia, skipping any sort of independence step
Russia need to justify it's invasion of Ukraine

This is one of those questions that I have a lot of uncertainty in and probably shouldn't try to answer that will probably bring my score down. Also I've had a fair amount of rum and it is 2 am. But I do think the consensus here is way too certain, and I think it's important to answer questions when you think the crowd is wrong.
Putin will always covet the Ukraine
This will give the Russian invasion more heft and be great PR for Russia
No, Invasion eminent
If there is an invasion by Russia, this would be the minimum.. If there is no invasion, this is the minimum "objectives achieved"..

There is a high degree of uncertainty here because the situation seems to be rapidly changing on the ground in Ukraine. Russia has so far insisted that these two regions be part of a weakened federal Ukraine, and not recognised their independence with that objective in mind. It is not impossible that it would change its position if its military intervention in Ukraine went poorly, but currently it seems this option is not very likely.
If Putin is in complete control, as I think he it, then this is probably already a done deal.
I am increase my forecast based on what appears to be a pretext for this conflict starting to overtly materialize in Russia: https://mobile.twitter.com/ragipsoylu/status/1494788414205579265
Initial forecast. Low hanging fruit. Another try with the Minsk Protocols, then it is probably done.

Owing to his fervent devotion to democracy, Vlad the Shirtless will bow to the will of the people as expressed in the Duma and recognize one or both of these shortly before he invades Ukraine to guarantee their independence. I figure some time in March for both the recognition and the invasion. (Full disclosure: Vlad the Shirtless seldom answers my letters, so I may have the date wrong.)
Continued tensions with Ukraine, following incursions in 2014, have raised the probability significantly.
